Side note: The NCNW produced three more cookbooks in the 1990s: The Black Family Reunion Cookbook, The Black Family Dinner Quilt Cookbook and Celebrating Our Mothersâ€™ Kitchens. They preserve African American culinary traditions and celebrate the strength and values of Black families.

NCNW programs prioritize four critical issues: education, with a special focus on STEM and early childhood literacy; educating women about health issues; encouraging entrepreneurship, financial literacy and job training; and advocating for sound public policy, voting rights and social change. /end

The NCNW functions as an â€œorganization of organizations,â€ serving as a unifying force for 37 national affiliate groups and more than 200 community-based sections, reaching nearly four million women. The organization focuses on the unique challenges Black women face due to both sexism and racism. /6

The NCNW established its national headquarters in Washington, D.C. in 1942. In 1990, it moved to the Dorothy I. Height Building, which is situated between the White House and the U.S. Capitol. The former headquarters, the Mary McLeod Bethune Council House, is now a National Historic Site. /5

Dr. Dorothy Height served as NCNWâ€™s president from 1957 to 1997 and expanded the scope of its mission. Under her leadership, NCNW played a significant role in the Civil Rights Movement, raising funds for the Montgomery bus boycott and developing programs to fight poverty in the rural South. /4

An early project of the NCNW was to assemble a cookbook that captured African American culture and furthered the cause of integration. The result was the Historical Cookbook of the American Negro (1958), which amplified heritage recipes with historical context to uplift Black women and families. /3

Bethune established the NCNW to unite Black womenâ€™s groups and address Black womenâ€™s concerns that were often ignored. In the midst of the Great Depression, NCNW aimed to tackle issues such as the inequality, housing discrimination and healthcare disparities that African American women faced. /2

#ResistanceRoots Today in history, 1935: Educator and activist Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune founds the National Council of Negro Women. The organization advocates for and empowers women of African descent, their families and communities, promoting education, entrepreneurship and civic engagement. /1

The study examined how artificial light at night influences individual behavior, population traits, and community diversity on aquatic invertebrates.
It disrupts the natural light-dark cycles to which organisms have adapted over evolutionary time, and which they depend on for critical biological processes.
Artificial light at night is one of the fastest-growing global pollutants, yet its ecological effects are often overlooked compared to issues such as chemical pollution or climate change.

Marine biologist Dr Lauren Smith, of East Grampian Coastal Partnership, said seven-arm octopus were a ""remarkable and rarely documented"" species. They live hundreds of metres below the surface of the sea and females, which are larger than males, can grow to 13ft (4m) long.

Also known as a septopus, giant gelatinous octopus or blob octopus, they have eight arms like other octopus - but in males one of the arms is also a reproductive organ that they attach to females when mating.

The resolution also urges Canada, Alberta and B.C. to recognize the climate emergency and uphold the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.

Hundreds of First Nations leaders are gathered this week in Ottawa for their annual December meeting, where high on the agenda was the federal-provincial memorandum of understanding for a bitumen pipeline to Asian markets announced last week.

Assembly of First Nations chiefs voted unanimously on Tuesday to demand the withdrawal of a new pipeline deal between Canada and Alberta, while expressing full support for First Nations on the British Columbia coast that strongly oppose the initiative.

Itâ€™s not always easy, but by approaching life philosophically â€” by actively, carefully considering matters from multiple perspectives â€” we can weigh things and take responsibility for our judgments and behaviors independently...

Indeed, evilâ€™s banality suggests its antidote begins in active thinking. By being sensitive to different viewpoints and scrutinizing everything we might otherwise adopt or conform to unconsciously, we can be guided by reason, rather than misled by rhetoric or propaganda.

In other words: evil spreads through shallow passivity, a lack of interest in engaging beyond the surface; expansive rational judgment is needed to keep goodness alive. Thinking carefully for ourselves provides a raft by which to navigate the daily waves of information, custom, and circumstance.

It is indeed my opinion now that evil is never â€˜radicalâ€™, that it is only extreme, and that it possesses neither depth nor any demonic dimension. It can overgrow and lay waste the whole world precisely because it spreads like a fungus on the surface... Only the good has depth that can be radical.

Arendt had Nazi Germany as her template, but argued systemic oppression and the gradual normalization of evil can occur anywhere, any time, and at any scale. Can you think of anything youâ€™re desensitized to today?

Arendt provides a warning here â€” for it is precisely our tendency to adopt judgments without thinking that allows evilâ€™s banality to flourish.

For these reasons, EPI opposes the proposed rule and strongly urges OSHA to withdraw this rulemaking. Gratitude to from me to: Margaret Poydock Senior Policy Analyst Economic Policy Institute

Employers in higher-risk industries have already adjusted to providing these basic protections since the OSH Act was passed in 1970, and there is no indication that the general duty clause generates an unstainable burden on employers.
The general duty clause is an essential component to the OSH Act that helps mitigate health and safety risks that we do not have existing standards for.
If the Department of Laborâ€™s deregulatory agenda is finalized, workers will be less protected from known and preventable hazards.

This includes regulations that require employers to limit workersâ€™ exposure to a variety of harmful substances (such as benzene, asbestos, lead, and cotton dust), regulations that require medical evaluations of respirators, and regulations that require color-coding to mark hazards.
Furthermore, at the time of this rulemaking, the Department of Labor has proposed amending or eliminating dozens of regulations that are designed to ensure workers have safe workplaces.

Therefore, the general duty clause is the only avenue for workers to be protected from extreme heat. There are a multitude of other health and safety risks that do not have OSHA standards, including protections against infectious diseases, ergonomic strains, and workplace violence.

For example, while OSHA is undergoing a rulemaking on whether a federal heat standard should be established, there currently is no federal heat standard in place for workers. This is a catastrophe as heat stroke kills more people in Australia than all the other natural disasters combined.
Exclusion from the general duty clause means these workers would no longer be protected from known and preventable hazards that do not already have an existing standard.

However, the rule also solicits commenters to provide additional industries for exclusion, which may result in a rippling effect of excluding all industries with higher safety risks, where the OSH Actâ€™s protections are most vital.
In OSHAâ€™s own estimates, at least 115,000 workers from arts, entertainment and sports occupations would be affected by the proposed rule.
The proposed carveout will result in a significant increase in preventable injuries among workers and a decrease in employer accountability.
The general duty clause is an essential component to the Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) Act by filling the gap for known and preventable dangers that do not have existing standards
The proposed rule would exclude certain occupations that are deemed â€œinherently risky professional activitiesâ€ from the general duty clause.
For years, EPI has conducted research on the importance of strong labor standards, including health and safety standards.

EPI conducts research and analysis on the economic status of working America, proposes public policies that protect and improve the economic conditions of low- and middle-income workers, and assesses policies with respect to how well they further those goals.
The Economic Policy Institute is a nonprofit, nonpartisan think tank created in 1986 to include the needs of low- and middle-income workers in economic policy discussions

We oppose the deregulation of this critical protection that holds an essential role in maintaining safe and healthy work environments and urge the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) to withdraw this proposed rule.
We strongly oppose limiting the scope of the general duty clause, which protects workers from known and preventable dangers where no other specific standard applies.

That is a non-standard definition of a ""subsidy"", one that is not used by any government or any other inter-governmental organization that produces estimates of subsidies to specific sectors. (Even other parts of the IMF don't conflate externalities with actual subsidies). See my ğŸ§·ed skeet for more.

That's an old number. The IMF's latest estimate is $7 trillion in 2022. However, ""only"" $1.3 trln of that are actual subsidies. The rest, $5.7 trln are the IMF's estimates of external costs related to the use of fossil fuels. (Note: the IMF does not estimate externalities related to production.)

3âƒ£ To be clear, the problem wasn't that the IMF started measuring externalities (except for traffic-related ones that they â€” in my view â€” wrongly attribute to petroleum products; but that's for later) but that they combined them with the price subsidies and called the total ""post-tax subsidies"".

2âƒ£ The basic problem traces back to 2013, when the IMF went from measuring consumer price (""pre-tax"") subsidies for fossil fuels and electricity to measuring also externalized costs (""externalities"" for short) related to the combustion of fossil fuels, like climate change and air pollution.

Since 2013, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has published biennially global estimates of what they call ""explicit"" and ""implicit"" #FossilFuelSubsidies. Those estimates are widely cited, but also widely misinterpreted & misrepresented. And some things they include shouldn't be.

But the state rejected the requests a week later. The agency said fulfilling the request would take â€œseveral hoursâ€ and cited a state regulation allowing a denial if providing information to a requester would require employees to â€œcompile or summarizeâ€ existing public records.

So on June 4, the nonprofit filed two public records requests with the Alaska Department of Public Safety concerning homicide cases the agency had investigated since 2022. The group asked first for victims of all races and then for those identified as Alaska Native.

In 2023, the state started publishing a list quarterly with names of Indigenous people reported missing. But the state still does not issue a list for the other key piece of the groupâ€™s efforts: Indigenous people who have been killed.
Over time, the nonprofit built its own homegrown database with the help of villagers, friends and family across the state.

Charlene Aqpik Apok launched Data for Indigenous Justice in 2020 after trying to collect the names of missing and murdered Indigenous people to read at a rally, only to discover no government agency had been keeping track.

Yet when an Alaska Native group asked state law enforcement officials in June for one of the most fundamental pieces of data needed to understand the issue â€” a list of murders investigated by state police â€” the state said no.

Federal legislation backed by Alaska Sen. Lisa Murkowski called for improving data collection and information sharing among law enforcement and tribes. Gov. Mike Dunleavy said again and again and as recently as May 5 that the state government would work with Alaska Natives to address the crisis.
Leaders in Alaska and elsewhere have repeatedly promised action in recent years to address the nationâ€™s chronic failure to solve the murder or disappearance of Indigenous people.
When the nonprofit Data for Indigenous Justice filed public records requests with the Alaska Department of Public Safety concerning cases it had investigated, the state rejected them.
Alaska Vowed to Resolve Murders of Indigenous People. Now It Refuses to Provide Their Names.

The worldâ€™s second biggest polluter, the US, was near the bottom, but 74% of its citizens still said its government should do more, while 48% were willing to contribute. New Zealand, Norway and Russia were also relatively low-scoring.

People in China, the worldâ€™s biggest polluter, were among the most concerned, with 97% saying its government should do more to fight climate change and four out of five willing to give 1% of their income. Brazil, Portugal, and Sri Lanka also ranked highly.
The 125 countries in the survey account for 96% of the worldâ€™s carbon emissions, and the results were published in the journal Nature Climate Change.
Our results suggest a concerted effort to correct these misperceptions could be powerful intervention, yielding large, positive effects.â€
Prof Teodora Boneva, at the University of Bonn, Germany, who was part of the team behind the 125-nation survey, said: â€œThe world is united in its judgment about climate change and the need to act.
A decades-long campaign of misinformation by the fossil fuel industry is a key reason the climate majority has been suppressed, researchers said.

Other studies demonstrate a clear global appetite for action, from citizens of rich nations strongly supporting financial support for poorer vulnerable countries and even those in petrostates backing a phase-out of coal, oil and gas.
The existence of a silent climate majority across the planet is supported by several separate analyses.

Dr Niall McLoughlin, at the Climate Barometer research group in the UK, said: â€œIf you were to unlock the perception gaps, that could move us closer to a social tipping point amongst the public on climate issues.â€

Prof Cynthia Frantz, at Oberlin College in the US, said. â€œCurrently, worrying about climate change is something people are largely doing in the privacy of their own minds â€“ we are locked in a self-fulfilling spiral of silence.

â€œOne of the most powerful forms of climate communication is just telling people that a majority of other people think climate change is happening, human-caused, a serious problem and a priority for action,â€ said Prof Anthony Leiserowitz at Yale University in the US.

Further analysis of the survey data for the Guardian showed that public backing for climate action was as strong among the G20 member countries as in the rest of the world. These states, including the US, China, Saudi Arabia, UK and Australia, are responsible for 77% of global carbon emissions.

The global average of those willing to contribute was 69%. But the percentage that people thought would be willing was 43%. The gap between perception and reality was as high as 40 percentage points in some countries, from Greece to Gabon.

In almost all countries, people believed only a minority of their fellow citizens would be willing to contribute. In reality, the opposite was true: more than 50% of citizens were willing to contribute in all but a few nations.
It also asked people if they would â€œcontribute 1% of their household income every month to fight global warmingâ€ and what proportion of their fellow citizens they thought would do the same.
The data comes from a global survey that interviewed 130,000 people across 125 countries and found 89% thought their national government â€œshould do more to fight global warmingâ€.
Making people aware that their pro-climate view is, in fact, by far the majority could unlock a social tipping point and push leaders into the climate action so urgently needed, experts say.

A huge 89% majority of the worldâ€™s people want stronger action to fight the climate crisis but feel they are trapped in a self-fulfilling â€œspiral of silenceâ€ because they mistakenly believe they are in a minority, research suggests.
The Guardian is joining forces with dozens of newsrooms around the world to launch the 89% projectâ€”and highlight the fact that the vast majority of the worldâ€™s population wants climate action.

341,000 Black women are still missing from the labor force since the pandemic began. This is the most educated female cohort in the country, and more than half are breadwinners for households with children. Erasing their economic participation undercuts todayâ€™s stability and tomorrowâ€™s workforce.

these forced exits alone are draining an estimated $9.2 billion from U.S. GDP this year. These arenâ€™t just missing paychecks; they represent lost productivity, lost tax revenue, and diminished national output.

The Exit Economy is here. If policymakers ignore it, Black women will continue to pay the highest price. But the cost wonâ€™t stop there. It will ricochet across households, communities, and the national balance sheetâ€”eroding the very prosperity America claims to protect.

Require the Federal Reserve to account for labor force exits, not just topline unemployment, in its models. And design stimulus not as across-the-board tax cuts but as targeted investment to keep womenâ€”and especially Black womenâ€”working.
Rebuild inclusive pipelines into higher-wage sectors like technology, finance, and government.
The numbers point to urgent, actionable solutions. Enforce pay and opportunity equity.

It cannot sustain Medicare and Social Security if over one million women are missing from the workforce. It cannot grow while concentrating Black women in the lowest-paid jobs and locking them out of higher-wage industries.
This divide threatens the very foundation of Americaâ€™s economic stability. An economy cannot remain resilient while sidelining its most educated women and breadwinner mothers.

Structural, not cyclical This is not a cyclical slowdown. It is a structural divide. The labor market is being carved up with precision: Women, and especially Black women, are being cut out. Menâ€™s gains are being supercharged. @daniellemoodie.bsky.social
Since February, the swing between black womenâ€™s losses and menâ€™s gains approaches 1 million jobs.

Expanding the analysis to reflect men overall, the gap has only grown more lopsided: Black women are down 297,000, but menâ€™s gains have surged to +621,000. Thatâ€™s a 324,000 widening of the gender gap in two monthsâ€”a 34% jump.
On August 31, when I last published an analysis of these figures, Black women were down 319,000 jobs while white men had gained 365,000.
Even as womenâ€™s participation remains structurally suppressed, men are re-entering the labor market at scale, reshaping the workforce in ways the topline numbers continue to obscure.
By contrast, since February alone, 879,000 men have entered the labor force. That divergence makes clear the gap isnâ€™t closingâ€”itâ€™s accelerating.

Meanwhile, Black women lost 1,500 jobs in government, a more stable and higher-paying sector, and saw zero gains in finance, transportation, or professional services. In short, they are gaining jobs where wages are lowest and losing them where wages are better.

This is the sector where Black women are concentrated and also among the lowest-paying in the economy. Average weekly pay in these sectors hovers around $530 to $1,200â€”far below wages in manufacturing, finance, or professional services.
The only meaningful job gains for Black women came in health care, food services, and social assistance: +10,700 positions in September.

In particular, vaccines have not only greatly reduced the risk of getting COVID and of becoming seriously ill from COVID; they also reduce the risk of suffering long-term damage from COVID, including damage to the brain.

So COVID's potential to damage the brain is just one more reason to do everything we can to avoid getting this disease. Masks and social distancing still are important, in crowded, indoor public spaces.
Fortunately, most people who get COVID don't suffer damage to the brain. But some do, and even people who initially get just mild COVID symptoms are vulnerable.

Finally, the lingering symptoms of fatigue, pain, and difficulty thinking that can last for several years after COVID â€” called long COVID or post-acute COVID syndrome â€” may well be caused by ongoing low-grade brain inflammation caused by the virus.
A large study of MRI scans taken before and then again after people got COVID showed that COVID can actually shrink the brain somewhat.
People who were initially severely ill with COVID are at much greater risk for cognitive decline after they recover. Even people who were less severely ill remain at a somewhat greater risk.

Even if people escape brain damage during the initial attack of COVID-19, they remain at considerably greater risk of various brain conditions, including strokes, depression, anxiety, and psychosis for the next several years.

A perfectly healthy 30-year-old son of a friend of mine experienced multiple strokes when he got COVID. COVID-related strokes can cause permanent difficulty in speaking or understanding speech, weakness on one side of the body, and other symptoms.

In addition, the virus that causes COVID can infect and injure the linings of blood vessels and make blood clot more easily. These two things can lead to strokes and heart attacks, even in young people.
It often damages the brain's autonomic nervous system, leading to abnormalities in heart rate and blood pressure.

COVID also can trigger the onset of new psychological disorders such as severe depression or anxiety. It can even cause people to become psychotic â€” to see and hear things that aren't there and to believe things that aren't true.

We now know that, unfortunately, COVID can damage the brain in many ways. When people first become sick from the virus, they may develop encephalitis â€” inflammation of the brain â€” causing confusion, difficulty concentrating, and memory problems. www.health.harvard.edu/mind-and-moo...
Economic burden of long COVID: macroeconomic, cost-of-illness and microeconomic impacts.

""We're still learning, still restoring our culture, restoring our connection to these things,"" he said. ""Learning the essence of them, the dreaming of it all â€¦ and it gives us hope for ourselves, our lives, our families and our future.""
Reconnecting with his Indigenous culture through astronomy is an ongoing journey of discovery for Wayne Thorpe.
""And what's really incredible is it seems it's older than Stonehenge.""

""We have â€¦ [a] stone arrangement, a traditional Aboriginal observatory,"" she said. ""The â€¦ stone arrangement is similar to Stonehenge, we can use it to track certain astronomical features throughout the time of the year.
""As long as we can see the sky we can see our stories."" Ms De Napoli said some of the oldest observatories in the world were in Australia.
Unlike on the land, where ancient land can be cleared and cultural trees chopped down, ""it's a little bit harder to chop the stars down"", he said.
""In our paintings and nature and the stars, if you can read them, you can read the deeper meaning of them."" Wayne Thorpe talked about the role of the night sky in preserving his culture.

Planets: Known as the wandering stars, Indigenous astronomers were able to differentiate the planets from the stars not only due to their 'wandering' nature, but also by the way they twinkled differently from stars and by the way they followed the Sun's path across the sky
Moon haloes: Indigenous Australians realised the connection of moon halo appearances in the sky with incoming rainfall, and were then able to use them to predict inclement weather.
Supernova: Indigenous astronomical traditions have recorded and described supernova (exploding star) occurrences dating back over 2,000 years

The Earth is round: Indigenous astronomers were able to track the way that the night sky shifts as their relative latitude would change. This indicated the spherical, curved nature of the planet and its sky, understanding the connection between latitude on the ground and declination in the sky
""When I look at the stars, it makes me want to tell a story, up there, it's a reflection of our dreaming.""

Mr Thorpe pointed to the Fishing Line, also known as Scorpius, on the other side of the Southern Cross, it is a hook flicking into a dark part of our galaxy. ""That's where the good fishing must be!"" he joked.
The Magellanic Clouds are a satellite galaxy orbiting the Milky Way. There are conflicting reports about when the Magellanic Clouds were first recorded in history.
He shared some of the traditional stories of the skies. ""We're standing under the Ancestors Camp in the Magellanic Clouds, see them there, sitting around their campfires,"" Mr Thorpe said.

Lake Tyers a perfect observatory Lake Tyers Aboriginal Trust in eastern Victoria is the perfect observatory â€” a hill with a view of the universe. Gunai man Wayne Thorpe lives and studies the stars here, where he is a traditional custodian of the land.
""I feel like it is something Australia should be really proud of, to be able to tell to the world we are the birthplace of one of these bits of knowledge and there's many examples like this.""
""Indigenous astronomers were able to see this change, and not only see this change, but describe it in a way that has the relative dimming of the different stars described over time.
""With variable stars there are subtle changes in their brightness over days and years, so it's something that takes a considerable amount of observation to determine their existence.

""One of my favourites is variable stars â€” we've known about them in Western astronomy for maybe 200 years, and yet when we look into Indigenous oral traditions there are descriptions of variable stars going back thousands of years.
""Places like Egypt and Greece are often quoted as being where scientific thought began, but amazing things were discovered here too,"" she said.
Kamilaroi woman and Monash University student astrophysicist Krystal De Napoli said that many early discoveries in Australian Indigenous astronomy preceded modern science by thousands of years.
Some of the earliest astronomy on the planet happened right here in Australia and the science of Indigenous astronomy is still relevant today.

They are currently trying to improve it. A subject that we, as the main agents of chaos, have a moral obligation to understand looks on the map like an enormous hole with a few ragged edges.

As one of the authors, Prof Antonio Gasparrini, told me, their extrapolation â€œwas moderate in some areas, but more extreme in others â€¦ in some cases the degree of extrapolation (especially geographical) was huge, and we cannot rule out that the model works less well in some regionsâ€.

The study had to model global trends from places in which data exist, which tend to be richer, cooler countries, where health systems are relatively strong. Thereâ€™s nothing I can see thatâ€™s wrong with the methodology: itâ€™s just that the records are so patchy.
This is in no way the fault of the authors â€“ itâ€™s simply a matter of where records are available.

Nor are most of the places in which healthcare is weakest, either for the population as a whole (as in some African nations) or for the most vulnerable people (as in the Gulf states, where citizens might be well covered, but migrant workers scarcely at all).

But the only African country covered is South Africa. Nor are there any data from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Afghanistan, the Gulf states (except Kuwait), Indonesia or Melanesia. In other words, most of the worldâ€™s hottest countries are not represented.
The paper explains that its dataset â€œcovers 750 locations in 43 countries or territoriesâ€.
The figures suggest that 58 times as many people there die of cold than of heat. While itâ€™s true that in hot places people are less adapted to cold, can this really be so?
In fact, sub-Saharan Africa appears to have the worldâ€™s highest rate of deaths from cold and the worldâ€™s lowest rate of deaths from heat.

The figure comes from a study using the widest available datasets to try to produce a global view. The results are, to say the least, surprising. For example, it suggests that even in the hottest parts of the world, more people die of cold than from heat.
Of course, they gloss over all the other impacts of climate breakdown: the storms, floods, droughts, fires, crop failures, disease and sea level rise. But is this claim, at least, correct?

What I wanted to discover was whether itâ€™s true that nine times as many of the worldâ€™s people die of cold than of heat. The figure is often used by people who want to delay climate action: if we do nothing, some maintain, fewer will die.
What Iâ€™ve now stumbled into is the vast black hole of our ignorance about these impacts.

I already knew that by burning fossil fuels, gorging on meat and dairy, and failing to make even simple changes, the rich world imposes a massive burden of disaster, displacement and death on people whose responsibility for the climate crisis is minimal.
I began by trying to discover whether or not a widespread belief was true. In doing so, I tripped across something even bigger: an index of the worldâ€™s indifference.

Al-Hissi, 25 years old, lived in northern Gaza with her 2-year-old daughter, Rita. During one Israeli airstrike, their home was bombed while she was holding Rita in her arms, trying to shield her from the blast. The child miraculously survived, but her mother lost both of her arms.

While trauma, poverty and austerity are not causes of each other, they are so interlinked that if we try to understand one without the others, we miss a crucial part of the picture.
The report suggests that austerityâ€™s undermining of the social safety net has made it easier to slip into poverty and made it harder to access treatment for trauma-related illness.

A 2020 report by Scotlandâ€™s Robertson Trust analysed the link between poverty and trauma extensively, arguing that while neither should be considered causes of the other, evidence consistently demonstrates an association between the two.
... the research still suggests that we must understand traumatic experiences as clustering among deprivation; as a structural issue that austerityâ€™s deepening of poverty has worsened.

As Professor Eamon McCrory of the UK Trauma Council has argued, exposure to trauma in youth and the chronic stress these experiences engender often make children more vulnerable to mental health issues in their adulthood.
Of those with PTSD, three quarters had another mental health disorder, one quarter were out of education or employment, half had self-harmed, and a fifth had attempted suicide.
A 2019 Kingâ€™s College study found up to 31% of young people had experienced traumatic incidents by age 18, with one in 13 of the general population having experienced PTSD.
... establishing that those from deprived areas experience higher rates of PTSD and tend to start treatment with more severe symptoms.
On top of isolation, the poverty austerity has caused has likely led to higher trauma exposure among young people.
Itâ€™s not hard to see how the disappearance of third spaces in which young people can develop social and supportive communities would be detrimental to a generationâ€™s mental health.

Young people with special educational needs were hit hardest by cuts, and the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Knife Crimeâ€™s 2019 report linked the rise in knife crime to the closure of youth centres.

Female-bodied Two Spirits were hunters, warriors, engaged in what was typically menâ€™s work and by all accounts, were always fearless.

Traditionally, Two Spirit people held positions within their tribes that earned them great respect ... conferrers of lucky names for children and adults... nurses during war expeditions, cooks, matchmakers and marriage counselors, jewelry/feather regalia makers, potters, weavers, singers/artists...

Traditionally, Two Spirit people held positions within their tribes that earned them great respect, such as Medicine Men/Women, shamans, visionaries, mystics, conjurers, keepers of the tribeâ€™s oral traditions...

The Two Spirit people in pre-contact Native America were highly revered and families that included them were considered lucky. Indians believed that a person who was able to see the world through the eyes of both genders at the same time was a gift from The Creator.

It was also a custom for parents to not interfere with nature and so among some tribes, children wore gender-neutral clothes until they reached an age where they decided for themselves which path they would walk and the appropriate ceremonies followed.
Native Americans traditionally assign no moral gradient to love or sexuality; a person was judged for their contributions to their tribe and for their character.

When the child would reach for the gender-corresponding hand, sometimes The Creator would switch hands and the child would have chosen the opposite genderâ€™s role and therefore casting its lot in life.

Some Siouan tribes believed that before a child is born its soul stands before The Creator, to either reach for the bow and arrows that would indicate the role of a man or the basket that would determine the role of a female.
The Native American belief is that some people are born with the spirits of both genders and express them so perfectly. It is if they have two spirits in one body.

Just as with all other aspects of the European regard for Indians, gender variance was not tolerated. Europeans and eventually Euro-Americans demanded all people conform to their prescribed two gender roles.
In 1530, the Spanish explorer Cabeza de Vaca wrote in his diary of seeing â€œsoftâ€ Native Indian males in Florida tribes dressing and working as women.

George Catlin said that the Two Spirit tradition among Native Americans â€œMust be extinguished before it can be more fully recorded.â€
The Jesuits and French explorers told stories of Native American men who had â€œGiven to sinâ€ and â€œHunting Womenâ€ with wives and later, the British returned to England with similar accounts.
For example, in the Iroquois Cherokee language, there is no way to translate the term, but the Cherokee do have gender variance terms for â€œwomen who feel like menâ€ and vice versa.
As the purpose of â€œTwo Spiritâ€ is to be used as a universal term in the English language, it is not always translatable with the same meaning in Native languages.

The Navajo refer to Two Spirits as NÃ¡dleehÃ­ (one who is transformed), among the Lakota is WinktÃ© (indicative of a male who has a compulsion to behave as a female), Niizh Manidoowag (two spirit) in Ojibwe, Hemaneh (half man, half woman) in Cheyenne, to name a few.
At the point of contact, all Native American societies acknowledged three to five gender roles: Female, male, Two Spirit female, Two Spirit male and transgendered. ictnews.org/archive/two-...

If not, suspected persons were to be brought to Germany, where special courts would decide their fate. To deter local resistance, the decree forbade these prisoners to have contact with loved ones and family members in their homeland.
Hitler responded by dictating that military courts would continue to adjudge those offences found sufficiently grave to impose capital punishment without lengthy proceedings.

Field Marshal Wilhelm Keitel, Chief of the German Armed Forces High Command, objected that it was impossible to sentence every potential resister to death and that military courts would, in any case, refuse to co-operate.

Hitler believed...managing resistance and sabotage through the system of military justice was far too cumbersome & often too lenient. He declared it to be an ineffective means of suppressing resistance. Instead, he ordered directives aimed at immediate, effective, & enduring intimidation...

German counter-intelligence redoubled its efforts, capturing large numbers of resistance members and saboteurs. This in turn meant an increased number of trials by overburdened military courts. In addition to a large number of death sentences, these courts also handed down many prison sentences.

The code name stemmed from Germany's most acclaimed poet and playwright, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749â€“1832), who used the phrase to describe clandestine actions often concealed by fog and the darkness of night.
This circumvented military procedure and various conventions governing the treatment of prisoners.

The ""Night and Fog"" decree was directed against persons in occupied territories engaging in activities intended to undermine the security of German troops. They were, upon capture, to be brought to Germany ""by night and fog"" for trial by special courts.

By the time the US Civil War was over, so was the US cotton industry. Egypt had ramped up to growing so much cotton, nobody really needed any from the US South anymore.

What actually happened? Egyptian cotton. With lots of fertile farmland and desperate for something to sell for cash on international markets, Egypt's leadership dumped resources into building up cotton farming in Egypt.

Without Southern cotton, the British textile industry would be brought to its knees. And that would force the British Empire- with the world's most powerful navy- to help the US South in its fight for ""freedom."" At least, that's what cotton plantation owners THOUGHT would happen.

The thing is, this isn't even the first time US ag has wrecked itself with foolish trade wars. In the runup to the Civil War, US cotton plantations decided to stop exporting cotton. Why? Because the British Empire's textile mills ran on cotton from US plantations.
